titleSet.title: Christmas Persian Poem composed by the Nizam of Hyderabad
"Navid-e Masih", the promised arrival of the Messiah
نوید مسیح

hra:item.hra:value: text-transcription-fa: "Navid-e Masih", the promised arrival of the Messiah
text-en: English version of the Christmas Persian Poem composed by His Exalted Highness The Nizam Of Hyderabad and translated by Sir Nizamat Jung, Ex-Member of Council
description-en: A Christmas poem in Persian composed by Osman Ali, the Nizam of Hyderabad, along with an English translation. Inside cover, Times of India Annual, 1940.

explanatory comments/crosstagging: At times even moulvis (religious priests) wrote messages of prayer and well wishes for the rich Muslims and presented in return for gifts or money. Incidentally, the Times of India Annual of 1940 (obtained from the Priya Paul collection) features a Persian Christmas greeting in verse that Mir Osman Ali, the last Nizam of Hyderabad, wrote presumably for the British monarch. It is printed with Islamic motifs and calligraphy and looks nothing less than a royal greeting card . (Yousuf Saeed)(gs)

related literature: Mathur, Saloni, "Wanted Native Views: Collecting colonial postcards of India," in Antionette Burton (ed.) Gender, Sexuality and Colonial Modernities, New York: Routledge, 1999, 95-115. (gs)
related literature: Patterson, Steven, Postcards from the Raj, Patterns of Prejudice, Volume 40, Number 2, Routledge, May 2006, 142-158; also see Saloni Mathur, 1999. (gs)
related hyperlink: Saeed, Yousuf 2011. "Eid Mubarak: Cross-cultural Image Exchange in Muslim South Asia." http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/117/index_1.html last accessed 2011-04-04 (gs)
